Award.AwardTitle: WiFiUS: Collaborative Research: Ultra-low latency and High Reliability for Wireless IoT

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The emerging Internet-of-Things (IoT) offers the promise of a wide range of new applications including control of critical infrastructure, mobile health-care, and industrial control. A key challenge for supporting many of these applications is to enable wireless networks to provide ulta-low latency and high reliability services. This project is developing new approaches to meet this challenge by furthering fundamental understanding of the control of wireless networks. As part of WiFiUS, the project is strengthening ties between the United States and Finland. Through the involvement of graduate students and the incorporation of results from the research into courses, the project is helping to develop the next generation of researchers.

This project is developing a new framework for supporting ultra-low latency and high reliability network services for emerging Internet-of-Things applications. These emerging applications often impose stringent requirements on both latency and reliability that cannot be met with existing techniques. The main idea behind this project is that latency and reliability are inherently coupled and must be addressed not just at the physical layer but also at higher network layers. The project's comprehensive research agenda addresses latency and reliability at various time scales, ranging from packet time scale and MAC layer scheduling to network deployment and the economics of their services. Specific tasks being targeted include:
1)Packet time scale optimization: Issues here include how messages are divided into packets, the length of time-slot used to send packets, and various physical layer parameters;
2)MAC time-scale optimization: The focus here is on scheduling traffic across different flows so as to meet the latency and reliability requirements of IoT tasks;
3)Network level time-scale: The focus here is on end-to-end reliability over a multi-hop network, by exploiting network diversity to ensure an adequate level of reliability; and
4)Network planning time-scale: Issues here include how networks are deployed and how sharing agreements are formed among network operators to enhance network diversity and reliability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed new frameworks for supporting ultra-low latency and high reliability network services for emerging Internet-of-Things applications. These emerging applications often impose stringent requirements on both latency and reliability that cannot be met with existing techniques. The main idea behind this project was that latency and reliability are inherently coupled and must be addressed not just at the physical layer but also at higher network layers. The comprehensive research agenda addressed latency and reliability at various time scales, ranging from packet time scale and MAC layer scheduling to network deployment and the economics of their services. This was a collaborative effort between researchers at Northwestern and MIT in the US and researchers at the University of Oulu in Finland.  At Northwestern, the focus was on the network planning time-scale and on studying how competition and cooperation among network operators impact the latency and reliability of services offered.  This complements work at MIT on packet/MAC timescale optimization and work at Oulu at the Network Level timescale.

Models have been studied to characterize how different aspects of the market for wireless services can impact network planning and the reliability and latency experienced by end users. One aspect that was considered is the bundling of both licensed and unlicensed spectrum together as a way for a service provider to improve the latency of their offered service.  The role of new technologies such as LTE Unlicensed (LTE-U) in facilitating this bundling was also considered.  Another aspect of the wireless marketplace is the role of Mobile Virtual Network Operator (MVNOs), who do not own their own network infrastructure but may cooperate with one or more service providers to offer a service. The impact of different market structures on the ability for such a MVNO to offer service was characterized.  Other market dimensions considered included the role of long-term contracts, the use of data reward plans and markets for spectrum occupancy information to facilitate better spectrum sharing.

 The project supported multiple PhD students and was the basis for 2 PhD theses. The PI publicized this work in part by giving invited talks in academia and industry.
